paragraphs.context: IMPRESSION: 1) Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities and numerous smoothly thickened septal lines. In a patient with history of CHF, these findings may reflect hydrostatic pulmonary edema. It is difficult to fully exclude the possibility of amiodarone lung toxicity, but the absence of significant hyperdensity in the liver would make amiodarone lung toxicity unusual (usually patient's with significant doses of amiodarone will demonstrate high density livers on CT scan). If the diagnosis remains in doubt clinically, consider a follow up high resolution CT after vigorous diuresis. 2) Moderate sized bilateral pleural effusions which are freely layering on prone images. 3) Mildly enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes, which can be seen in the setting of CHF, but are non-specific. 4) Small bilateral calcified pleural plaques, suggestive of previous asbestos exposure. 5) Low density right adrenal lesion suggestive of adenoma.

The ground-glass opacities are again demonstrated on these images. Assessment of the central airways reveals a focal polypoid lesion in the lateral wall of the trachea posteriorly at the level just above the aortic arch, probably due to retained secretions.
Assessment of the soft tissue structures of the thorax reveals several lymph nodes in the mediastinum in the prevascular and paratracheal regions. paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT INDICATION: Peripheral vascular disease, upper extremity edema, need for IV access, right arm being preserved for veins to harvest.
PROCEDURE/FINDINGS: The procedure was performed by doctors [**Name5 (PTitle) 6365**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 109**], the attending radiologist, who was present and supervising throughout the procedure. As no suitable superficial veins were identified, ultrasound examination of the left upper extremity was performed, revealing the left brachial vein to be patent and compressible. The area was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. Local anesthesia was achieved with subcutaneous injection of 3 cc of 1% lidocaine. Under real time ultrasound guidance, the left brachial vein was accessed using a 21 gauge micropuncture needle. Hard copy pre- and post-puncture images were obtained with ultrasound. A 0.018 guidewire was then advanced through the needle and into the SVC under fluoroscopic guidance. Based on the markers on the guidewire, the PICC was trimmed to a length of 42 cm. The needle was then exchanged for an introducer sheath. The PICC was then advanced over the wire through the sheath. The peel-away sheath and wire were then removed. The catheter was then aspirated, flushed, capped, and heplocked. The line was then secured with a Statlock device and a sterile transparent dressing applied. A final limited chest radiograph confirmed placement of the tip of the catheter to be in the distal SVC. There were no immediate post-procedure complications. The line is ready for use.
